platform.title: Download CLI
platform.description: Choose the platform/OS where you intend to install the CLI and click on the corresponding Download button below:

create.description: Please provide a name for your workload (alphanumeric characters only), and also optionally add a description for this workload.
create.inbound_traffic_info: Choose 'Disabled' option if the workload will not receive any traffic from other applications or services, for example, this workload will only generate traffic destined for upstream services.
create.workload_from_template_info: Please provide a name for the workload you'd like to create from an available template (alphanumeric characters only).
create.workload_from_template_title: Create Workload From An Available Template
create.publish_warning: This will publish the workload. Are you sure you want to publish this workload ?
create.template_description: To create a workload from template , enter a name using alphanumeric characters. Name should not contain any special characters.

helpText.myWorkloads_config: Your configured workloads are listed below. You can manage individual workloads through the corresponding ACTIONS menu, or you can create a new workload by clicking on the NEW WORKLOAD button.
helpText.myWorkloads_not_config: You haven't configured any workloads yet. Click on the NEW WORKLOADS button to begin creating your first workload.

general.description: Specify general details about your workload on this page.
general.name: Name

ingress.description: Specify ingress configuration for your workload on this page.
ingress.atleast_one_ingress_error: You must configure at least one ingress policy
ingress.field_empty_error: Empty fields detected in your ingress policy. Please correct and continue
ingress.no_certificate_error: You must select a certificate before you continue
ingress.invalid_host_name_error: Please provide a valid host name, Valid characters are a-zA-Z0-9
ingress.cert_cname_and_host_mismatch_error: The server name in the certificate you have selected does not match the configured ingress host name
ingress.host_unique_error: Host names configured as part of an ingress policy must be unique
ingress.mutual_authentication_text: Select from the list of supported authentication mechanisms if you would like to limit access to the upstream API services only to authenticated users.
ingress.cname_create_info_text: IMPORTANT: You must create a CNAME for this workload via your DNS service and point to:
ingress.cname_create_info_text2: Because you are using our domain, your traffic will be encrypted using System Provided certificates.
ingress.atleast_one_api_path_msg: You must configure atleast one API Path. Please correct and continue.
ingress.delete_ingress_warning: Are you sure you want to delete this Ingress ?
ingress.delete_path_warning: Are you sure you want to delete this Path ?
ingress.url_paths_helptext: This platform natively supports API routing policies, which you can define here for your devices or endpoints to connect to over the Internet. For each defined path, you can specify if you want to send the payloads accessing the path to an external service or a micro-service running in the workload context. You will be able to specify specific external services or containers before publishing. Please note that you cannot repeat a URL Path in this configuration.
ingress.no_slash_URL: URL Paths must begin with forward slash.

settings.description: Customize application related settings on this page.
settings.name: Name

containers.description: This page is where you describe the containers that make up this workload.
containers.description_2: For each container, you can also configure ports, image tags, environment variables, and other critical features.
containers.helptext: Your configured containers are listed below. You can view or edit specific container configuration by clicking on the edit button in line with the container name. All containers within a namespace can interact with each other using the service_name:port combination.
containers.field_empty_error: Empty fields detected. Please correct and continue.
containers.no_containers_configured_info: You haven't configured any containers yet. Click on the NEW CONTAINER button to begin creating your first container.
containers.delete_container_warning: Deleting this container will require changes to the API Routing policies that may have already been defined. Are you sure you want to do this?
containers.atleast_one_container_error: You must specify at least one container
containers.logs_helptext: Enable automatic collection and aggregation of log output from all container replicas to configured aggregation endpoints.
containers.download_cli_desc: If you haven't already, please use the CLI utility to push your container image to the platform's container repository.
containers.discourage_latest_tag: Example: index.docker.io/rafaysystems/testapp:v2 , please avoid using "latest" tag for container images
containers.deploy_description: General settings of the workload helps to identify the workload by Name and description. Workload can be deployed with API G/W ( for ingress traffic ) or stand alone ( without API G/W).
containers.health_check_inline_desc: Use this feature to configure readiness and liveness probes for this container. Readiness checks are carried out once when a container is started and if the check is successful, your container is deemed operationally ready. Liveness checks are carried out periodically for the lifetime of the container; a failed liveness checks means that your container is no longer operational. For HTTP/S health checks, please specify Header(s) to be sent with the request below.
containers.liveness_same_as_readiness: Check this box if you want to use the same logic to test for readiness and liveness
containers.interval_helptext: how frequently the container will be probed
containers.metrics_inline_desc: Use this feature to configure metrics collection for this container.
containers.success_threshold: Success Threshold (# of probes before container deemed UP)
containers.failure_threshold: Failure Threshold (# of probes before container deemed DOWN)
containers.shared_volume_inline_desc: Use this feature to define volumes that you'd like to share across all containers defined within this workload. You can always define container-specific volumes within the container configuration page if needed.
containers.delete_shared_volumes_warning: Are you sure you want to delete this Shared Volume.
containers.data_export_endpoints_inline_desc: Use this feature to select the logs endpoint where logs generated by containers within this workload should be sent. You can define logs endpoints under "Integrations > Aggregation Endpoints".
containers.name: Name
containers.auto_scale_help_text: Specify the minimum and maximum number of container replicas youâ€™d like the system to spawn in each cluster. Please also specify the mean CPU threshold that the system should target across running containers. Replicas will be added when the mean CPU usage exceeds the configured threshold value for 30 seconds, and will be removed when the mean CPU usage is below the configured threshold value for 5 minutes across the current replicas.
containers.auto_scale_custom_metrics_help_text: Scale containers by the metrics exposed from the container using Metrics Endpoint defined. The average value is calculated every 30 sec of moving window of 5 mins for very metric exposed and max number of containers are launched aganist all metric thrsholds.
containers.auto_scale_invalid_error: Min replica count should be less than or equal to max replica
containers.auto_scale_scale_up_help_text: Step up rule will be evaluated every 30 sec and if the conditon is true autoscaler will scale up the instances in the percentage provided. cpu and memory are reserved key words for CPU and Memory. The Values of CPU and Memory are average utilization values like 80% used in last 5 min. Where other metrics are rate of increase like http_requests is 200 requests/sec in last 5 mins. For specific time window per metric in minutes can be used as {minutes}
containers.auto_scale_scale_up_help_instance: eg: if 2 instances are running and expression is true in 30  sec and 10% is configured to scale up then one more instance will be added making total instances to 3. If 100% is configured 2 more instances will be added making total instances to 4
containers.auto_scale_scale_down_help_text: Step down rule will be evaluated every 30 sec and if the conditon is true for 5 mins autoscaler will scale down the instances in the percentage provided. cpu and memory are reserved key words for CPU and Memory. The Values of CPU and Memory are utilization values like 80% used.
containers.auto_scale_scale_down_help_instance: eg: if 4 instances are running and expression is true for last 5 mins and 50% is configured for scale down then 2 instance will be removed making total instances to 2. If 100% is configured auto scaler scales down to minimum instances
containers.container_security_inline_desc: Use this feature to configure readiness and liveness probes for this container. Readiness checks are carried out once when a container is started and if the check is successful, your container is deemed operationally ready. Liveness checks are carried out periodically for the lifetime of the container; a failed liveness checks means that your container is no longer operational. For HTTP/S health checks, please specify Header(s) to be sent with the request below.
containers.lifecycle_hooks_inline_desc: Use this feature to configure readiness and liveness probes for this container. Readiness checks are carried out once when a container is started and if the check is successful, your container is deemed operationally ready. Liveness checks are carried out periodically for the lifetime of the container; a failed liveness checks means that your container is no longer operational. For HTTP/S health checks, please specify Header(s) to be sent with the request below.
containers.node_affinity_inline_desc: Use this feature to configure readiness and liveness probes for this container. Readiness checks are carried out once when a container is started and if the check is successful, your container is deemed operationally ready. Liveness checks are carried out periodically for the lifetime of the container; a failed liveness checks means that your container is no longer operational. For HTTP/S health checks, please specify Header(s) to be sent with the request below.
containers.pod_affinity_inline_desc: Use this feature to configure readiness and liveness probes for this container. Readiness checks are carried out once when a container is started and if the check is successful, your container is deemed operationally ready. Liveness checks are carried out periodically for the lifetime of the container; a failed liveness checks means that your container is no longer operational. For HTTP/S health checks, please specify Header(s) to be sent with the request below.
containers.pod_anti_affinity_inline_desc: Use this feature to configure readiness and liveness probes for this container. Readiness checks are carried out once when a container is started and if the check is successful, your container is deemed operationally ready. Liveness checks are carried out periodically for the lifetime of the container; a failed liveness checks means that your container is no longer operational. For HTTP/S health checks, please specify Header(s) to be sent with the request below.

affinity.required_during_scheduling_label: Required During Scheduling Ignored During Execution
affinity.preferred_during_scheduling_label: Preferred During Scheduling Ignored During Execution

policies.description: This page is where you define various policies for the workload, including API routing and container upgrade
policies.description_2: For each API Path, please specify where the received requests should be sent. Requests may be sent to a container (specify relevant service name and port), or to an external service.
policies.hints_for_custom_policy: Hints: You can select the required clusters from the list below.
policies.hints_for_developer_policy: Hints: You can select the required locations from the list below.
policies.latency_label: Target Round-trip Time Between End Point And Closest Cluster (in milliseconds)
policies.placement_policy_line_1: Where, in relation to your users and endpoints, do you want to deploy this workload? You can choose one of two policy options.
policies.placement_policy_line_2: If you're testing a development build or simply kicking the tires, we recommend you use the DEVELOPER placement type, which will limit your workload footprint to two Clusters worldwide.
policies.placement_policy_line_3: If you are ready to experience the benefits of cluster deployment and want to evaluate performance benefits, set the placement type to PERFORMANCE and subsequently select the round-trip time (RTT) in miiliseconds that you believe will most improve the end user experience.
policies.placement_policy_line_4: If you wish to only run your app in certain parts of the world, you can choose the SPECIFIC LOCATIONS option and pick locations that are of interest to your business.
policies.placement_policy_line_5: Select the clusters where you wish to deploy your workload.
policies.placement_policy_line_6: If you wish to run your app in certain clusters, you can choose the SPECIFIC CLUSTERS option and pick global clusters that are of interest to your business.
policies.placement_policy_line_7: If you wish to run your app with certain labels, you can choose the CUSTOM LABELS option and pick custom labels that are of interest to your business.
policies.probes_configure: Please configure probes to all the containers for Rolling Upgrade to be seamless

edge_refinement.title: Cluster Refinement
edge_refinement.description: This section allows you to change the defaults that govern workload allocation across additional clusters when a new cluster of users is detected on the Internet. Note that you can optionally choose to only expand the current workload footprint, or only contract clusters.
edge_refinement.target_percentile: Use this configuration to describe the percentage of end users or endpoints for whom you want to ensure that the configured service-level object (in terms of Round-Trip Time) is met.
edge_refinement.refinement_interval_description: Specify how often the system must review collected metrics to determine if the target percentile is presently being met or not.
edge_refinement.min_datapoints_per_sec_description: Specify how many new latency-related data points must be received by the system across all clusters per second before the system should review the current workload footprint.
edge_refinement.threshold_description: Specify how many refinement cycles you want the system to wait before a new decision is made about adding or removing clusters for this workload.
edge_refinement.tolerance_description: Specify how quickly the system should take action based on changes in end user or endpoint population globally. If the RTT experienced by a cluster of users changes by more than the tolerance level relative to the configured RTT objective, clusters may be added or removed accordingly.

publish.description: This page is where you can initiate the deployment of your workload at the Cluster. Clusters will be selected based on your configured placement policy and infrastructure resources available to your organization.
publish.config_error: There appear to be errors in your workload configuration.
publish.config_error_info: The system has detected the following errors in your workload configuration. Please correct these so that you can successfully publish this workload.
publish.publish_failed_error: Failed to publish the workload. Please try again.

You can use PUSH CONFIGURATION button to push your configurations to the workload.

desc.host_2: The existing workloads need to be republished to start using the new updated vault config

fields.name: Enter a name for your EKS cluster
fields.region_k8sversion: Select the AWS region for the EKS Cluster
fields.availability_zones: Specify Availability zones for the cluster
fields.service_role_arn: Specify your previously created service role ARN
fields.service_role_permissions_boundary: Specify your previously created service role permissions boundary policy arn

networking.description: Specify Endpoint Access, VPC and Subnets for your cluster node groups

fields.vpc_cidr: Specify a range of IPv4 addresses for your VPC
fields.vpc_nat_mode: Specify the NAT Mode for your VPC

fields.node_group_name: Enter a unique name for your managed node group
fields.instance_type: Choose the instance type to use in your managed node group. Larger instance types can accommodate more pods
fields.spot_instance_type: Choose the instance type to use for your spot instances. Larger instance types can accommodate more pods
fields.nodes: Enter the current number of worker nodes that your managed node group should maintain at launch
fields.Nodes_min_max: Specify the minimum number of worker nodes that your managed node group can scale in to
fields.nodes_min_max: Specify the maximum number of worker nodes that your managed node group can scale out to
fields.node_ami: Specify based on GPU & non-GPU instances
fields.ec2_ssh_key_name: Specify your Amazon EC2 SSH key to use
fields.instance_profile_arn: Specify your previously created instance profile ARN
fields.instance_role_arn: Specify your previously created instance role ARN
fields.instance_role_permissions_boundary: Specify your previously created instance role permissions boundary policy arn
fields.managed_node_group: Select to provision optimized groups of nodes- each scoped to a single Availability Zone for your cluster. Note: Managed nodegroups do not have complete feature parity with unmanaged nodegroups
fields.wavelength_node_group: Select to provision the node group in wavelength zone
fields.wavelength_subnet_config: Specify network configuration to provision wavelength zone resources
fields.security_groups: Specify your previously created security group's ID
fields.node_availability_zones: Specify availability zones for the nodegroups
fields.node_subnets: Specify VPC subnet IDs for the nodegroup
fields.node_labels: Automatically assign the configured labels to all nodes in the node group
fields.aws_tags: Underline resources will be automatically created with the specified tags
fields.use_spot_instances: Specifies the distribution of On-Demand Instances and Spot Instances, the maximum price to pay for Spot Instances, and how the Auto Scaling group allocates instance types to fulfill On-Demand and Spot capacity.
fields.volume_encrypted: Specifies whether the volumes are encrypted.
fields.volume_kms_key_id: Specifies the optional KMS Key Id to be used for volume encryption.
fields.OnDemandAllocationStrategy: Indicates how to allocate instance types to fulfill On-Demand capacity.
fields.OnDemandBaseCapacity: The minimum amount of the Auto Scaling group's capacity that must be fulfilled by On-Demand Instances. This base portion is provisioned first as your group scales.
fields.OnDemandPercentageAboveBaseCapacity: Controls the percentages of On-Demand Instances and Spot Instances for your additional capacity beyond OnDemandBaseCapacity.
fields.SpotAllocationStrategy: Indicates how to allocate instances across Spot Instance pools.
fields.SpotInstancePools: The number of Spot Instance pools across which to allocate your Spot Instances.
fields.SpotMaxPrice: The maximum price per unit hour that you are willing to pay for a Spot Instance.

service_roles.description: Choose the service roles that will be attached to EKS Node Groups

fields.ecr_access: Enable IAM role for accessing Amazon ECR
fields.alb_ingress_controller: Enable IAM role for ALB configuration
fields.cloudformation_role_arn: IAM role used by CloudFormation to call AWS API on your behalf

list.title1: Create, view and manage custom cluster blueprints.

list.title: All cluster blueprints are composed of one or more software addons. Cluster administrators can assemble one or more addons to create a custom cluster blueprint. Good candidates for "addons" are components that are well suited as cluster wide services. For example, an Ingress Controller etc.

detail.title1: Create and view current and historic versions of configured addons.
detail.title2: NOTE: All operations related to lifecycle of addons can also be embedded into an automation pipeline using the RCTL CLI.

list.title: Create and manage the lifecycle of CD agents to enable secure connectivity to your private Git and Helm repos. It is recommended to configure multiple agents for availability and scalability.

agents.create: Create a new agent and associate it with a managed Kubernetes cluster to enable secure connectivity to your repositories

configure.name: Provide a name for your repository
configure.endpoint: Provide the URL where your repository can be reached
configure.network_access: Select Public if your repository is accessible on the Internet
configure.disable_ssl: Select this if your repository does not require https for access
configure.ca_certificate: Required if your repository uses a private certificate authentication. Provide your repositoryâ€™s CA certificate in PEM format
configure.credential_type: Select the method you would like to use for the agent to authenticate so that it can securely access your repository
configure.username_password: Enter an authorized username and password/token combination
configure.ssh_private_key: Provide the SSH Private Key in PEM format
configure.agents: Select one or more agents from the list that can reach your repository's endpoint

clusterOverrides.create: Create and configure a new Cluster Override.

general.description: Specify your general details of the cluster overrides here

fields.name: Name of the Cluster Override
fields.type: Name of the Cluster Override type

selector.description: Specify your Resource Selector and labels for the cluster overrides here

fields.labels: Specify your resource selector labels here
fields.configType: Specify your Override Configuration type here
fields.relPath: Specify your Git file name and git path here

list.title: Create and manage declarative, GitOps based, multi-stage automation pipelines for application delivery and lifecycle management on Kubernetes

pipelines.create: Create and configure a new GitOps pipeline

detail.title1: Ensure that you activate the pipeline if you want it to be automatically executed based on external triggers. Deactivate the pipeline to temporarily or permanently pause trigger based execution.
detail.title2: Click on Run to manually execute the pipeline. Click on Edit to and reconfigure the pipelineâ€™s stages and triggers.

stages.name: Provide a user friendly name for the stage
stages.action: Select the type of action for the stage
stages.approval_type: Select the approval type from the dropdown list
stages.emails: Specify one or more email address that will be sent an email for approval
stages.timeout: Specify how long the stage will wait for all approvals before timing out (Eg. 100s). Use "0s" to set no timeout
stages.onfailure: Specify the action you would like to perform upon failure of the stage
stages.workload: Select the workload you would like deploy from the drop down list

triggers.title: Create and configure external triggers that will execute the pipeline. Note that it is possible to configure multiple triggers to drive the same pipeline.

configure.name: Provide a unique name for the trigger
configure.type: Select the type of trigger from the available options. Webhook triggers are automatically pushed from the monitored repository. Use a Crobjob if your repository does not support webhooks.
configure.repository: Select the repository from the dropdown list that you would like to associate with the trigger
configure.repo_type: Select the type of repository from the available options
configure.payload: Specify the payload format for the webhook from the available options
configure.periodicity: Specify how frequently (minutes) the specified repository will be polled to detect changes
configure.cron: Specify the sync frequency in Cron time string format e.g, 0 0 * * * (Minute, Hour, Day, Month, Week)
configure.chartname: Specify the name of the Helm chart and Revision
configure.repo_revision: Specify the revision for which triggers will be created
configure.repo_paths: Optionally specify the paths for which triggers will be created

locations.title: Configure and manage locations where backups will be stored

configure.name: A unique name for the backup location
configure.target_type: Select Target type for Backup Location
configure.bucket_name: Enter the name of the S3 Bucket
configure.container_name: Enter the container of the Storage Account
configure.resource_group: Enter the name of the Resource Group
configure.storage_account: Enter the name of Storage Account
configure.region: Enter the AWS region code. For example, us-east-1
configure.s3_url: Enter the URL for the S3 Endpoint. For example, https://minio.example.com

agents.title: Create and manage the lifecycle of Data Agents to perform backup and restore operations on your cluster

list.title: Your configured workloads are listed below. You can create a new workload template by clicking on the NEW WORKLOAD TEMPLATE button.

workloadtemplate.repository: Provide the repository to be used for the workload template
workloadtemplate.revision: Provide the revision to be used for the workload template

version.header: Create a new version of a gatekeeper config based on the configuration provided below
version.version_name: Provide a unique version for the gatekeeper config
version.installation_params: Provide the installation parameter for this gatekeeper config
version.sync_objects: Add Kubernetes objects to be synced into OPA.
version.excluded_namespaces: List of namespaces excluded from certain processes for all constraints in the cluster.
version.constraints: The list of constraints that will be part of this gatekeeper config

detail.title1: Provide the configuration for a new version of the gatekeeper config.
detail.title2: NOTE: All operations related to lifecycle of gatekeeper config can be automated using the RCTL CLI.
detail.no_versions_help: Create a new version of a gatekeeper config

list.title1: Create, view and manage custom gatekeeper configs.
list.title2: NOTE: All operations related to lifecycle of blueprints can also performed using the RCTL CLI via an automation pipeline.

configure.git2systemSync: Select to automatically reconcile changes in Git to downstream clusters
configure.systemSync2git: Select to automatically reconcile changes from the controller to your Git repository
configure.sourceRepo: Select the source repository, the branch and folder path
configure.destinationRepo: Select the destination repository, the branch and folder path
configure.includedResources: Select which resources you want to include from the list
configure.excludedResources: Select which resources you want to exclude from the list
